# TESS Program G011209
            
Title: Tess Views An Eclipss

PI: Ayres, Thomas - University Of Colorado

Type: N/A

Summary: In 2018, HST's Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) will carry out a far-UV survey ("EclipSS") of 49 carefully-chosen nearby solar-type (F2-K2) dwarfs, located near the ecliptic poles. These areas are favored by two important up-coming missions: TESS (photometry/exoplanets) and eROSITA (X-ray all-sky survey). The targets were chosen to be isolated (good for TESS and eROSITA), bright enough for TESS and eROSITA, but not too bright for super-sensitive COS. FUV emissions and X-rays are tracers of stellar activity, for which TESS can provide supporting rotation periods, flare frequencies, and seismology. The multiplexed sample will provide an unprecedented view of the magnetic engine - the Dynamo - at the heart of activity, which among other things can affect exoplanets and their habitability.   


# Sector 001 targets observed (15)
